title: Will the IAEA verify that Iran's uranium stockpile has been reduced to less than 300 kg of low-enriched uranium before 1 June 2016?
preds:
IAEA Director General Yukiya Amano’s statement on Iran:
https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/iaea-director-general%E2%80%99s-statement-iran

"inspectors on the ground verified that Iran has carried out all measures" agreed under the agreement.
https://www.yahoo.com/news/un-report-iran-deal-compliance-likely-saturday-sources-200039241.html
Yes. IAEA HAS VERRIFIED. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35335078 We should all Suggest Resolution.

Latest is that the report will come on Saturday...
http://uk.reuters.com/article/iaea-report-on-irans-compliance-with-nuc-idUKL8N14Z40Z

Yes, we expect this to happen tomorrow, actually. So tomorrow we should press that Suggest Resolution button, it looks like. "The IAEA will issue its final report on Friday to confirm Iran has met its commitments under the JCPOA," Deputy Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi said, according to the Fars news agency.http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-iaea-idUSKCN0UR1NH20160113
I figure verification will come shortly in advance of the announcement of Implementation Day. We'll see what happens next week.

The Iranians have shown a compelling interest to comply with the nuclear agreement in exchange for the lifting of sanctions. The recent prompt release of U.S. citizens following a maritime incident reflect their decision to forge ahead with renewed diplomatic engagement and cooperation. However, "hardliners" continue to hold considerable sway in Iranian politics, and the Supreme Leader could choose to reverse course.

almost there...
http://www.cbsnews.com/news/iran-nuclear-deal-iranian-compliance-coming-days-john-kerry/ one report of a delay with the decommissioning and filling core with concrete over at the bbc, but just a formality at this point.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-35302628
Iran is evidencing commitment towards fulfilling terms, I have increased optimism

I think Iran will keep to its promise, as much as it may not want to. Iran's troubles in the ME are growing and should not want to exacerbate issues with the US at this time. However, the hardliners may try to push for Iran to back out of the deal to show that they are strong and can handle multiple enemies.
IAEA are vested in the agreement going through.

Yes Factors: 1. Iran pursues conventional weapon rather than nuclear ones
2. Iran wants to uncover the isolation of its economy. No factors: 1. US isn't sincere in making nuclear deals. 2. Iran's hardliners hamper the deals.
Increasing based on Iran's determination to have sanctions removed.

If enough people want something badly enough, almost anything can be overlooked, redefined, or permitted to slip through the cracks.  Quick demonstration of this principle: The perfection of the United States in the eyes of Americans.

Iran is there now.

Back to 90 IAEA will certifiy asap.keep treaty on track. Iran was in substantial compliance.

Stockpile has been reduced, so just waiting for IAEA to verify.

Announcement of the shipment increases the probability because the inspectors can now go ahead with their verifications

+"Iran has shipped all of its low-enriched uranium to Russia." -- http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Iran/US-hails-Iran-shipment-of-low-enriched-uranium-stockpile-to-Russia-438767 +"There is no evidence that Iran is planning to depart from a deal reached with world powers last year to scale back its nuclear program and it could even fulfill all of its agreements this month, a German foreign ministry spokesman said on Monday."-- http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-germany-idUSKBN0UI10M20160104 +"IAEA found no credible evidence of recent atomic-weapons activity after 2009." -- http://www.wsj.com/articles/iaea-finds-some-iranian-nuclear-weapons-activity-continued-after-2003-1449078659 +“This removal of all this enriched material out of Iran is a significant step toward Iran meeting its commitment to have no more than 300 kilograms of low-enriched uranium by Implementation Day.” -- John Kerry

"Iran has shipped all of its low-enriched uranium to Russia." -- http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Iran/US-hails-Iran-shipment-of-low-enriched-uranium-stockpile-to-Russia-438767
"IAEA found no credible evidence of recent atomic-weapons activity after 2009." -- http://www.wsj.com/articles/iaea-finds-some-iranian-nuclear-weapons-activity-continued-after-2003-1449078659
“This removal of all this enriched material out of Iran is a significant step toward Iran meeting its commitment to have no more than 300 kilograms of low-enriched uranium by Implementation Day.” -- John Kerry

Yes, the whole process appears now to be moving faster than expected. We could see this by the end of February. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/01/01/461610337/as-iran-moves-swiftly-on-nuclear-deal-sanctions-could-go-soon

Yes factors: Iran pursues conventional weapon rather than nuclear ones; Iran wants to uncover the isolation of its economy. No factors: US isn't sincere in making nuclear deals. Iran's hardliners hamper the deals.

Delivery to Russia just happened https://www.rt.com/news/326527-iran-ships-uranium-russia/.
They are left with 300 kg. Only need to be approved by the IAEA. Still residual small risk if not completely the truth.
It appears to be done. All that remains is the IAEA verification.

http://nanonews.org/irans-uranium-stockpile-turned-over-to-russia-under-nuclear/ Under the nuclear accord, Iran has to remove all its nuclear material enriched as much as 20% that was not already in the form of fabricated fuel plates for the Tehran Research Reactor. . . .  the withdrawal volume amounted to “over 8.5 tons” of low-enriched uranium material. “This removal of all this enriched material out of Iran is a significant step toward Iran meeting its commitment”, . . . . Kerry . . .  thanked Kazakhstan for its help in supplying Iran with the non-enriched uranium it received in exchange for surrendering its stockpile and Norway which helped manage and fund the operation to conduct the transfer.

We are close with the news about the shipment of Uranium but not quite there, since the question requires IAEA verification of 300kg or less.  See Kerry's actual statement: http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2015/12/250876.htm "This removal of all this enriched material out of Iran is a significant step toward Iran meeting its commitment to have no more than 300 kg of low-enriched uranium by Implementation Day. . .. The IAEA now must verify that Iran’s enriched uranium stockpile is 300 kg or less, as well as confirm that Iran has met all of its other key nuclear steps in the JCPOA before Implementation Day can occur. " So its a "significant step" but its not a done deal yet. Still will probably happen before June.

Iran ships 25,000lb of low-enriched uranium to Russia as part of nuclear deal.
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/28/iran-ships-uranium-russia-nuclear-deal

Iran took the most important step so far toward complying with the nuclear agreement it had signed with the P5+1 power by shipping 25,000lb of low-enriched uranium to Russia. Iran had until the end of 2015 to ship out all of its low-enriched uranium it has stockpiled – except 660lb which the agreements allows it to keep.
http://www.homelandsecuritynewswire.com/dr20151229-iran-ships-enriched-uranium-to-russia-as-part-of-nuclear-deal

This pretty much seals the deal
http://www.todayonline.com/mideast/iran-hands-over-stockpile-enriched-uranium-russia

Updating for the story noted in multiple sources today (see links noted by other forecasters below). My "two cents" is  that a determination of resolution should likely not occur until such time that the residual amount is actually verified by the IAEA. From the following:
http://thediplomat.com/2015/12/iran-deal-update-11000-kilograms-of-enriched-uranium-leave-iran-for-russia/ "In order for the JCPOA to advance to that stage, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) must certify that Iran has successfully complied with the technical requirements of the deal and adequately reined in its nuclear program. Under the JCPOA, Iran concedes a great deal of its civilian nuclear infrastructure, but retains limited capacity to enrich uranium and operate centrifuges. Once the IAEA certifies that Iran has complied, “Implementation Day” will take effect, releasing roughly $100 billion in overseas Iranian assets that have been frozen under international sanctions."

Because of Sanction pressure, Iran will be making an effort to be as transparent as possible. At least in the medium term.

"Russia has completed withdrawing enriched uranium from Iran as part of an agreement between Tehran and the world’s six powers on the Iranian nuclear issue, a Russian diplomatic source familiar with the agreement’s implementation told TASS on Monday. "This procedure has been completed," the source said."

up on news of planned, 9 ton uranium shipment to Russia. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-idUSKBN0U208420151219 (thanks for the link @cmeinel)

Reuters - ‎Saturday‎, ‎December‎ ‎19‎, ‎2015
Iran ready to ship enriched uranium stockpile to Russia "Iran will export most of its enriched uranium stockpile to Russia in the coming days as it rushes to implement a nuclear deal and secure relief from international sanctions, Tehran's nuclear chief was quoted as saying on Saturday.
"In the next few days around nine tonnes of Iran's enriched uranium will be exported to Russia," nuclear chief Ali Akbar Salehi was quoted as saying by state news agency IRNA. That is roughly the amount that Iran must export to bring its stock down to the required level.
On Wednesday, Tehran said it was working to complete the requirements in the next two to three weeks, after the International Atomic Energy Agency closed its investigation of Iran's past nuclear activities.
IAEA chief Yukiya Amano, responsible for verifying that Tehran has taken the necessary steps, said it is "not impossible" that sanctions could be lifted in January, ahead of important Iranian elections in late February."
Up 5% on the news of planned transfers.
The shirtless one and turbaned one will make it so.

Upward revision of forecast from 84% to 88% Three reasons:
1. International monitors closed their probe into military aspects of Iran’s past nuclear activities on Tuesday in Vienna, a key step toward implementing July’s accord with world powers and lifting sanctions against the Islamic Republic [1]  2. More importantly, the IAEA gave Iran the green light to export 8.000 ton of enriched uranium, allowing it to move towards 300 kg  [2] 3. The export of 8.000 does not bring the total below the 300 kg in my calculations based on the IAEA values in the report [3], Iran has in total the equivalent of 12,639.6 kg of 3.5 percent LEU hexafluoride. The inventory is 8,305.6 kg of 3.5 percent LEU hexafluoride and the equivalent of another 4,334 kg of 3.5 percent LEU hexafluoride in various chemical forms at the EUPP. This stock of 3.5 percent LEU has increased by 460 kg since August 2015 [3]. Doing the math, exporting 8.000 ton would leave 4.639 ton of material. Therefor not only 88% and not higher.
Insights are welcome into this point. 1.  http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-02/iran-undertook-nuclear-bomb-studies-before-2009-iaea-finds
2.  http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-14/iaea-to-close-iran-weapon-probe-in-key-step-for-ending-sanctions
3.  http://isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/ISIS_Analysis_IAEA_Report_November_18_2015_Final.pdf

Totally didn't realize the implication of the link I shared on another question ("Implementation Day") --> http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/58039 Dec 7: "Russia expects Iran nuclear deal to be implemented in January" --> http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-idUSKBN0TQ1II20151207 Russia's envoy to the U.N. nuclear agency said on Monday he expected a historic nuclear deal between Iran and world powers to be implemented in January, leading to sanctions being lifted on Tehran. Under the deal, Iran must scale back its nuclear program, including its stockpile of low-enriched uranium, which it plans to do via a swap for non-enriched forms of uranium with Russia. That swap will be done before the end of the year, the Russian envoy to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) in Vienna, Vladimir Voronkov, told reporters in Vienna. Iran has made it a precondition for fulfilling all its promises under the July agreement that the board of governors of the IAEA formally close an inquiry into Iran's nuclear past with a resolution on Dec. 15.  ~~
Seeing austerity's forecast for this question reminded me about this question.

http://tass.ru/en/world/842049
"Russia and Iran will complete the removal of enriched uranium from Iran in exchange for natural one by the end of the year, Russia’s UN envoy in Vienna, Vladimir Voronkov, has told TASS.
"This will certainly happen by the end of the year," he said, adding that both the removal of nuclear material from Iran and the delivery of natural one to Iran would be completed within that deadline.
Russia will supply natural uranium and uranium concentrate (yellowcake) to Iran. Voronkov said the details of the deal were being finalized at the technical level."
It would be hard to believe that they would go through the treaty process to not meet the goals

Far from being the whitewash some had predicted, a new report by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) states clearly that Iran had a nuclear weapons program until 2003 and continued some research for six more years.
http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/12/iaea-iran-report-nuclear-weapons-program.html?utm_source=Al-Monitor+Newsletter+%5BEnglish%5D&utm_campaign=529c1cb6f2-December_03_2015&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_28264b27a0-529c1cb6f2-102297633 Let me clarify - I dropped my % because I am closer to believing the IAEA will issue a non political report, and even if it were a condemning one it would skip the inflammatory language we have come to expect from opponents and remain basically a non partisan report.
Just being modest, is all, as my prior prediction of 99% was rather unbecomingly self-confident.

Up to 90 from 85 on 01 Nov forecast. This is an essential part of the deal, and the only reason I'm not going higher is because the logistics could be challenging. Iran has reportedly picked much of the low hanging fruit by dismantling almost a quarter of its centrifuges in just a few weeks, according to the IAEA (though these were mostly idle anyway). Six months remain.

http://www.jpost.com/Blogs/A-Mid-East-Journal/The-Russo-Iranian-missile-deal-434470 " . . . on October 21 Iran’s Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Khamenei, published a document laying down nine new requirements before Iran would agree to implement the JCPOA. These unilateral conditions fundamentally change what was agreed on July 14, and virtually declare the JCPOA a dead letter. " For example, under the JCPOA Iran is obligated to start changing the function of its nuclear reactor at Arak and shipping out most of its stockpile of enriched uranium as a precondition for the lifting of sanctions. In his document Khamenei declares that Iran will not carry out these actions until after the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) closes its dossier on Iran, targeted for December 15. But how can the IAEA report by the target date about Iran meeting its obligations, when Iran is not even going to begin doing so by then? In short, the JCPOA has been thwarted from the very start. "So far the US and the EU appear to have turned a blind eye to Iran’s new position on the nuclear deal, but if Khameini means what he says and acts on it, they will surely have to defer the lifting of sanctions.
I am less optimistic that this will occur. Revising down my estimation.

The inventory is 8,305.6 kg of 3.5 percent LEU hexafluoride and the equivalent of another 4,334 kg of 3.5 percent LEU hexafluoride in various chemical forms at the EUPP. http://isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/ISIS_Analysis_IAEA_Report_November_18_2015_Final.pdf Logic: what actually happening points in a different direction AND there are sources of enriched material in different forms and within reactors that also count towards the 300 kg.

Iran continues to work at warp speed at complying with the nuclear treaty. Implementation day in the first week of January? Time to get rich! As for those bah, humbug hardliners – their glory days are fading. Dateline 11-28-15 Iran is pitching 70 oil and natural gas projects valued at $30 billion to foreign investors at a two-day conference in Tehran that started today as the Persian Gulf country prepares for the end of sanctions that have stifled its energy production. All banking and economic sanctions will be lifted by the first week of January,” Amir Hossein Zamaninia, deputy oil minister for international and commerce affairs, said at the event. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-28/oil-majors-queue-up-in-iran-with-30-billion-of-projects-in-play  Dateline 11-25-15 Iran expects a deal it reached with world powers in July, under which sanctions will be lifted in return for it scaling down its nuclear program, to be implemented at the start of next year, Iranian nuclear negotiator Abbas Araqchi said on Tuesday. "We expect early January," Araqchi told reporters after meeting the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which is tasked with verifying whether Iran is keeping its commitments under the deal. Iran is holding parliamentary elections on Feb. 26 and diplomats say Tehran has been working hard to fulfill its commitments under the nuclear deal before that date.

Based on the current reduction of uranium stockpile, it appears likely to be completed before this date.   Report of Reuters and other publication (today) indicate the level reduced and how much remains to be completed.  The variance is extremely high.

This agreement has reached the stage where hemming and hawing have replaced quacking and flapping almost entirely.  Despite anybody's misgivings, this boat will remain unrocked for at least another year, I'd say.
Am not convinced the stockpile actually will be reduced but Iran could make it appear so and IAEA would not want to jeopardize the agreement.
Raising 5% on expectation the PMD will be at least neutral and because things seem to be on track in spite of comments by the Supreme Leader.
Upping prob. in light of Clinton's info.
Don't need to be so close to an end.

Revising downward slightly based on dismantling hiccup.

Lowering estime give the report in Reuters today on halting dismantlement at two Iranian nuclear sites.  It's impact is still unclear and does not necessarily imply that this will remain the path through the requirement of IAEA reporting on December 15.   I suspect however that statements reflecting the Supreme Leader's thoughts (in Iran's theocracy) have not been specified in the media at this point.  The current resolve toward not meeting dismantlement requirements reflect an internal dispute between parliamentary forces and the President.   This could also possible imply that the internal matter could move toward an external dispute with the IAEA verification requirements.   Dismantle is structures and affect the stockpile that Iran holds and will in the future.   It is possible that the regime could use non verifiable measures to unload part of its stockpile not specified in the agreement.  However, it is likely that the IAEA be able to access such action resulting in a reportable dispute.

Neither major party to this agreement is interested in seeing that goal attained in that time frame. They each have their own motivations. This agreement is a means to another end.
Nor do I believe that the sanctions will remain lifted in the long term.
Iran is going to play along and skirt by on the edges of verification while blasting America all along.
if they are not below this level,knowledge of the future inspections gives them the opportunity to destry any overages or whatever options that are available.

Iran is going to "train" the IAEA and intl community to accept tardy and half-hearted compliance.  There is no downside in this for them as there will be no consequences  (and it placates the hardliners domestically).   The only reason my percentage is so high is that Iran could just hide the excess (cheating has been and will continue to be a pattern for Iran, as it was for N. Korea).
Despite all the arm waving and strong wordings it is obvious that the Iranians are willing to take the necessary steps and deliver on their side of the nuclear deal.
Main stream media hasn't picked up the HuffPost item, so raising.

They have strong incentives to demonstrate compliance with the agreement at this early stage while hot attention governs particularly US politics and non-compliance is more likely to quickly invite re-introduction of key sanctions.  Any fudging is more likely to be more low-key and develop later, when the sea has calmed down.

Iran says it will probably trade the enriched uranium for natural uranium. They seem to be in talks with someone to this end. It looks like everything is on track to compliance. I don't anticipate problems.
The visible stockpile will be verified to be in compliance.  Determining if this is the full stockpile will be problematic and open to disagreement by various countries.

So far, there has been no real opposition by the people of Iran. 
The key here will be how their economy grows. If the opposition of Iran doesn't have enough economic incentives, they may not want the IAEA to verify (whether true or not) that their stockpile has been reduced. The recent test firing of a missile was to appeal to the conservatives and not a sign of scuppering the nuclear deal (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/12/world/middleeast/iran-tests-long-range-missile-possibly-violating-nuclear-accord.html)
Furthermore, there is a common enemy in fighting ISIS which will take center stage over the nuclear deal until a better coordinated political solution regarding ISIS is met (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/29/world/middleeast/syria-talks-vienna-iran.html)

Needs letter from IAEA mid december to start the process, and iaea seem to have confirmed to iran they will do so by 15 december.  http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/iran-nuclear-deal-challenges.html# and http://en.trend.az/iran/nuclearp/2451494.html.  Then Iran has three options to reduce LEU stockpile down: " Tehran has three options for disposing of the remaining portion of its current LEU stockpile: diluting the material so that it contains the same levels of uranium-235 found in natural uranium; selling the LEU to another country; or selling it to an international LEU bank recently established by the IAEA."  source - https://fas.org/sgp/crs/nuke/R43333.pdf.  The LEU bank could buy the lot if need be (90t hold with only 10t in Iran).  Statements such as "transferred, based on a commercial transaction, outside of Iran or diluted" (fas again) make me think it may not even have to physically move for IAEA to give the green light on this.  Finally, if they cannot to the deals then dilution seems easily achievable - http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20151020/world/Deal-on-Iran-programme-to-be-implemented-this-year.588943

A little confused about this, is the question will they be able to verify or will they confirm?

In order for the Iranians to get sanctions relief and gain access to billions of Dollars of their frozen assets, they need to comply with certain measures including reducing their stockpile of enriched uranium. I predict that they will do so before June 1, 2016.
Iran wouldn't have signed onto this treaty with the intent of violating it so soon.

Probably to show they are in compliance with this major agreement. Although Khamenei is openly opposed to it or states Iran will do what it wants, it might be more just lip service. Adjust to crowd because I am ignorant of this topic.
won't be able to be certain of anything due to stalling
Tensions in the ME are rising; consequently, Iranian compliance with the agreement is less likely.
In most important actors' interest that Iran fulfills this obligation.

According to El Baradei Iran has never had the aspirations to pursue nuclear bomb. So that makes the chances more than 50 percent. How much more? Well this can't be saidin particular because UAE's foreign minister was recently said to be saying the nuclear option (for civilian purposes) could also be considered. Officially he said its their right to enrich to just like other nations. But in reality it's most likely to create greater parity with Iran in terms of the timeline for a race to nuclear bomb. Japan for example, is at any point (or was before the disaster struck), several weeks away from a bomb. So in that case, Iran may want to hold on to those stockpiles just to see long enough what GCCs do or require IAEA or international community to promise similar inspection standards for them too.

Iran  will not try to blatantly test the agreement and risk the continuation of sanctions at this early stage - especially during the US election campaign with so many hawkish candidates happy to take issue.  Still, there could be some logistical issues - where will the 9,700 kg go, how will they be transported, what are the commercial terms, etc; hence the 27% risk of technical non-compliance during the transition which may not be complete by June 1st 2016.
There is strong incentive for Iran to reduce the stockpile as fast as possible. Waiting beyond this point is risky, especially considering the election (US) coming up.
On the surface it's to the intrest of all involved, but Iran will use the agreement to expand their influence .
Iran will not want to risk re-imposition of sanctions.  Better lives for average people will slightly keep momentum moving toward global cooperation.
They have to. If they do not, it will all come crashing about their heads.

With Iran coming to the fore front of the Syrian conflict (boots on the ground) and the turmoil building between the US and Russia over the bombing of US backed rebels. Can the US and it's allies stand having its hands tied from finger pointing during the escalating conflict? Their are to many issues in Khamenei's letter *http://www.leader.ir/langs/en/index.php?p=contentShow&id=13791 that will allow Iran to constantly delay. In number three - not being accused of human rights violations. I think Iran will delay till after the US Presidential election since most republican candidates want a way to drop the deal.

Neither side of the political aisle wants to "know the answer" as to whether or not the Iran nuclear deal proves successful in 2016, for the following reasons:
1) The U.S. presidential election takes place in December 2016, and both republican and democratic presidential candidates will prefer to stick with unfalsifiable rhetoric rather than risk learning that the Iran's actions of compliance or noncompliance following the nuclear deal contradict their and/or their party's original predictions.
2) With Russia now deeply involved in Syria, the U.S. and the Obama administration would rather have Iran's support against ISIS, and, in exchange, delay verification of uranium stockpiles in Iran, at least until the next administration takes over in 2017. Instead, we will continue to rely on intelligence for insight into Iran's actual (or perceived) action in fulfilling their end of the nuclear deal.
3) With the global economy still somewhat sluggish, possibly on the decline with China lowering their predictions of annual economic growth to between 6% to 7% for years to come,  and the U.S economy still somewhat on the rise, helped by low fuel prices, the U.S. is hesitant to increase conflict with Iran, which would raise oil prices. Not "knowing the answer" for certain allows the U.S. to keep a blind eye and focus on further stabilizing and growing its own national economy, in hopes of raising interest rates for the first time in a decade.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/18/world/middleeast/iran-nuclear-deal-sanctions.html?emc=edit_th_20151018&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 Oct 17.  "Iranian engineers on Sunday are expected to begin executing one of the largest and most complex projects of nuclear dismantlement in history. They have to mothball 12,000 nuclear centrifuges, ship more than 12 tons of low-enriched fuel — 98 percent of Iran’s stockpile — out of the country and destroy the core of a giant plutonium reactor. "The engineers insist they will finish the job in record time in order to get the more than $100 billion in sanctions relief promised in the nuclear agreement Iran signed last summer . . . 
. . .
" . . . Whether it is a historic success and a major part of President Obama’s legacy or a failure could be determined by whether the work of carrying out the deal is marked by strife over what constitutes compliance and what constitutes cheating. "Nonetheless, [Iranian Foreign Minister] Zarif also promised that the work of dismantlement would be done by the end of November. "To pacify hard-liners who oppose the whole idea of the dismantlement, Tehran over the past week has test-launched a medium-range ballistic missile  . . .  At a Friday news conference, Mr. Obama said that while “Iran has often violated some of the prohibitions surrounding missile testing,” the recent agreement solved a separate problem of “making sure that they don’t possess a nuclear weapon.” "Playing to its domestic audience, Iranian television recently took viewers on a tour of a previously secret underground missile site, and an Iranian court convicted a Washington Post reporter on dubious espionage charges, with not-so-subtle hints that he could be traded for Iranians imprisoned in the United States. " . . . One hard-liner in Parliament who seemed to have a grasp of those details threatened to kill the head of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, Ali Akbar Salehi, who had negotiated the specifics with the United States energy secretary, Ernest J. Moniz, and to bury Mr. Salehi’s body “in the cement of the Arak heavy-water reactor.” ". . .  Mr. Zarif and President Hassan Rouhani know that if Iranians are to see the benefits of sanctions relief by the time of elections next March — seen as a referendum on the Rouhani government — the slow process of freeing up the money must begin almost immediately. "History suggests it may take much longer. South Africa took nine years to dismantle most of its nuclear program, which had even produced atom bombs before its end was ordered in 1990. The main effort was completed with the decommissioning of an enrichment plant in 1999. Iran, which denies that it ever sought to make nuclear weapons, is stopping short of that: Natanz, Iran’s main enrichment site, will remain open, with 5,000 centrifuges.  . . . 
. . . 
For years, Iranian officials have ducked the questions, arguing that they are based on documents fabricated by Israel and the United States and that Iran’s experiments have been for peaceful purposes.  . . .  "Then there is the issue of inspections. . . .  the agency’s overstretched inspection staff is supposed to monitor the Natanz and Fordo enrichment plants . . . Piping and electrical gear from the production lines will also be dismantled. . . .  "At Fordo, a group of centrifuges will be converted into a production line for stable isotopes . . .  "The hardest job is likely to be repurposing the reactor at Arak. Engineers are to transform it from a plant for making weapons-grade plutonium, another bomb fuel, into an industrial producer of radioactive isotopes used for such purposes as diagnosing ills and treating cancer. "A senior Obama administration official, briefing reporters last month, repeatedly declined to make a firm estimate of when Iran would finish the job. “It’s going to be at least months,” the official said, speaking on diplomatic ground rules of anonymity. “They clearly have motivation to try to accomplish those steps as soon as possible. But look, this is a very complicated deal.”

From the link provided by GJ: http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2015/04/240170.htm it looks like IAEA has some leeway in its declarations. Perhaps it could, in a pinch, decide that the stockpile is appropriately reduced if the material is merely moved from wherever is it now to one of the IAEA secure facilities to be established in Iran. As cmeinel pointed out, IAEA showed this kind of flexibility over Parchin. According to that state.gov link, Iran currently has a stockpile of 10 tonnes of enriched U. Physically reducing that by 97% to 300 kg by moving it all across the border is a logistics problem, as several forecasters have pointed out, but not as big as it first appears. There is a well-established industry for moving this stuff around. See
http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Nuclear-Fuel-Cycle/Transport/Transport-of-Radioactive-Materials/ Let's assume the enriched U exists because it was intended for a sprint to bomb-grade material. It would then likely be stored the form of uranium hexaflouride (hex) so that it would be ready to feed a gas centrifuge. There are standard containers for transporting this kind of stuff (see above link). One of them is a so-called 30B, about a meter across and two meters long, holding 2 tonnes of hex. 10 tonnes of U translates to about 15 tonnes of hex, so we're talking about 8 type 30B containers, each of which could be transported in a pickup truck. Okay, an American pickup like a F350 or a Ram, not one of those dinky Toyotas you see all over the middle east, but still --- eight truckloads.  Not so bad. We don't know how it is stored, but 30Bs are likely candidates for that, too, because hex is chemically such nasty stuff. If you can buy a standard set of couplings and learn a standard set of handling procedures that have 50 years of industry experience built in, why would you go reinvent it? Iran's intention may be malicious, but that doesn't make their engineers stupid. Jean-Pierre points out that Ulyanov says there are "technical difficulties" involved in the set up. I'm going to be charitable and take that as a diplomat's use of the term "technical," meaning who is involved, who has authority, who foots the bill, etc. etc. -- in other words, the technicalities of the human factors. That kind of technicality could well stretch out a timeline, but they are also amenable to a swift kick if they get in the way of other priorities. Physical technicalities are not. So, I'm going to follow Jean-Pierre's original instinct and start at 75%

I've been hung up on how Iran would physically meet the requirement implicit in the Question. An earlier "fact sheet" that I read threw me off because it stated that the excess LEU had to be removed from Iranian soil. I've flipped my forecast on this because, after re-reading Paragraph 57 of the actual Agreement (or at least what I believe to be the Agreement), I find no such requirement, and it seems that Iran can achieve this "reduction" contractually (via a transfer of legal title); and while the word "delivery" is used in the Agreement, there does not seem to be any requirement that the delivery must involve the physical removal of the material out of the country. I can imagine some dingy warehouse where this stuff is dumped, under IAEA surveillance, with a sign on the stocks saying "Property of IAEA" while awaiting completion of the IAEA fuel bank in Kazakhstan. Here's the factsheet that threw me off: http://www.bnonews.com/files/images/IranNuclearDeal.PDF It uses the words "soil" and "exported" which are not in the Agreement.

Assuming Adoption Day occurs before end-October, that gives seven months for Iran to move 12000 kg of uranium, plus have the remaining stockpile level verified by the IAEA as being under 300 kg. I believe Iran wishes this deal to be successful, however am sceptical that all the logistical and trust issues can be overcome prior to June 1. Suspect it will be later in 2016.

Upping  a little bit in light of news that Parliament likely to approve (or something like it) JCPOA on Oct. 11 with "Adoption Day" scheduled for Oct. 18. From there: "Among other measures, Iran must remove thousands of centrifuges from its Natanz reactor, ship overseas all but 300 kilograms of 12,000 kilograms of enriched uranium and remove the center of its plutonium reactor, the officials said. Because of how involved the measures are, the officials would not estimate how long it would take to get to “implementation day,” when the IAEA confirms compliance and sanctions are lifted. Reports have indicated that Iran is likely to comply with conditions in from between six months to a year from adoption of the deal."
http://forward.com/news/breaking-news/321162/iran-deal-formal-adoption-will-take-place-october-18/#ixzz3nnxxdeEi So June 1 is approximately 9 months out. My general sense is that Iran wants to sanctions lifted quickly, and that transferring the stockpile seems like a reasonably straightforward thing to check off the list. (Reactor removal and dismantling the centrifuges would seem to be things that are more technically challenging.) I'm guessing the stockpile is reduced by spring, maybe earlier.
They have 15 years. No need to rush.

Upon reading the technical annex I find the following: "Unless otherwise specified, the durations of the commitments in this Annex are from Implementation Day." Then: "Iran may choose to seek to sell excess enriched uranium to the IAEA fuel bank in Kazakhstan when the fuel bank becomes operational." It seems otherwise specified, so Iran needn't do this by 2016 to get rid of sanctions, and from what I have read they are cozy with the Kazakhs so it seems a logical place to send it, and the bank won't be operational till 2017

Iran wants sanctions relief, that was the rationale for the deal. The IAEA verifying is a prerequisite for the sanctions relief. If adoption takes place in October, and it takes 6 months for Iran to get ready, and maybe a month or two for the IAEA to verify. Iran could conceivably ask for an extension on this measure until the Kazakh fuel bank opens, but given it's early-going and they want to get out from under sanctions it seems unlikely. And the political climates in the P5+1 nations would make any concessions or signs of backsliding unlikely. Iran will meet set-out parameters to get free from sanctions.

"Iran may choose to seek to sell excess enriched uranium to the IAEA fuel bank in Kazakhstan when the fuel bank becomes operational."

http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/UF-IAEA-and-Kazakhstan-agree-to-create-nuclear-fuel-bank-27081501.html Hmm. So where does it go until 2017? I'm flipping my forecast because I believe this is the intended destination, and I can't see them shipping it twice. Look for a waiver or extension on this imo.

Regardless of whether Iran will or will not ACTUALLY REDUCE is stockpile below 300kg, I believe the IAEA will "verify" that it has.  This is a prediction of what the IAEA will do, NOT what Iran will do.
Due to election related uncertainty in the US, and possible presidential candidates threatening to review the agreement if they win, Iran may need to save face by also grandstanding.

"Implementation Day is the date on which, simultaneously with the IAEA report verifying implementation by Iran of the nuclear-related measures described in Sections 15.1. to 15.11 of Annex V ..."
(See link from Raisinville below)
The only "required" IAEA verification report, therefore, seems related to the reporting of the entire set of nuclear-related measures, not to any specific measure, such as reduced LEU stockpiles in particular. So, assuming the IAEA intends to make no informal item-by-item progress reporting, this Question becomes a proxy for Implementation Day  (assuming no specific measures can be waived, etc.).

Link to the "Join Comprehensive Plan of Action" dated 14 July, 2015: https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/2165399/full-text-of-the-iran-nuclear-deal.pdf The State Department link provided in the "More Info" section is a preliminary 2 April, 2105 document, not the final agreement, this document includes the following lines:
" Important implementation details are still subject to negotiation, and nothing is agreed until everything is agreed. We will work to conclude the JCPOA based on these parameters over the coming months."
Iran plays "good-dog" and IAEA wants to be viewed as doing its job.

In the "Inspections and Transparency" section of "Parameters for a Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action Regarding the Islamic Republic of Iran's Nuclear Program" It is stated that "...the IAEA will have regular access to all of Iran’s nuclear facilities, including to Iran’s enrichment facility at Natanz and its former enrichment facility at Fordow, and including the use of the most up-to-date, modern monitoring technologies." 
Monitoring activities to be effective must be carried out on regular basis,  1 June 2015 appears, at the moment, a fair date.

Iran has committed itself to this target, and will make every effort to achieve it asap, once the agreement clears its Parliament. There may be problems of logistics, but at this early stage I'm confident of a positive outcome.

Rouhani wants to get this done ASAP to benefit from sanctions relief, and he's talking about an early 2016 implementation day [1]. There's no obstacles on the Western side. But, 2 things are making me cautious:
1) Possible obstacles to implementing the deal within Iran: primarily from Khomeini & hardliners.
2) Sanctions might be relieved (ie Implementation Day happens) without Iran reducing its stockpile. Redacted has suggested this is possible. Anyone got specific info on this? Nevertheless, I'm broadly confident this will happen. Will raise if I see information that assuages my 2 doubts.  [1] http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/25/iran-nuclear-deal-hassan-rouhani
Both parties (iaea and Iranian govt) have strong motivations to " produce this outcome "
Not sure about the May 31st date.  Already forecast the sanctions will not be lifted due to delays: so a low forecast to start.
Initial forecast. Starting here based upon the work of cmeinel and redacted.  Agreed that Iran will want to appear cooperative.

Making a high prediction on the basis of three factors. 1.  Iran was quick to get over the Parchin inspection hurdle. 2. Iran now has an intelligence sharing agreement with Russia and Iraq regarding Syria. Iran also has publicly sent ground forces to Syria, in addition to the advisers who have been there for some time. This suggests that Iran and Russia also are prepared to collaborate quickly on removing the uranium. 3. Elections in February could lead to greater hardliner influence. Moderates could be motivated to accomplish as much as possible before the hardliners might get into a position to delay things. Sources: Dateline 10-2-15 Russia has urged the United States to join an intel-sharing center with Syria, Iran, and Iraq that was announced last week to deep surprise in the United States.https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/russian-warplanes-strike-deep-inside-islamic-states-heartland/2015/10/02/ace6dfcc-6866-11e5-bdb6-6861 Dateline 10-2-15 In late February 2016, Iran will see two important elections. One is for the Assembly of Experts, a constitutional body. The other is for the Majlis, Iran’s parliament. As Iran prepares for the vote, the power struggle between the hardliners and the moderates and reformists is intensifying. This showdown, even more than the discussions about the Iran deal negotiated by the P5+1, will shape Iranian politics in the years and decades to come. Foreign Affairs This Week [newsletters@e.foreignaffairs.com]

I am surprised that the actual process Iran must undertake to achieve this objective seems to still be up in the air. To have not locked this down in detail appears to be a significant defect in the agreement. Destruction or irreversible conversion under observation would have been preferred (at the expense, of course, of those parties that demanded its destruction). Alternative methods of achieving this objective might involve both bulk and continuous transportation of very large amounts of LEU or refabricated LEU around the globe. Not sure how prudent that is. Regardless, I'm increasing my forecast since it seems Iran will want to do this, or at least want to appear to do this, as soon as possible.

Iran hoping implementation day will be already early 2016: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/25/iran-nuclear-deal-hassan-rouhani

They had/have about 12000kg.  They need to arrange where, when, and how to ship it off, and what to receive in exchange.  That might all take some time to arrange.   From [1], (senior administration official 2) says:
"Iran currently has a stockpile of around 12,000 kilograms of enriched uranium hexafluoride or the equivalent in other chemical forms, and it needs to get the vast majority of that material out. This is going to be somewhat complicated for them to do. They haven’t shipped material like this out of the country. And so they have to get that total amount down to 300 kilograms. Again, we expect the process to start on October 18th and then take months after that to implement all of these steps." So, it will be complicated and take months.  But, possible.  Russia has been discussed as potential taker.   Regarding "Implementation day" - implementation day is the day when the IAEA says conditions are in place so that agreement can be implemented. At present, I am trying to:
1) Find a source document that specifies a "performance date" ("date certain') for this objective /obligation; and,
2) Find a source document that describes in detail the responsibilities of the IAEA in respect to this particular objective / obligation; and,
3) A description of a clear path by which Iran may actually achieve this objective / obligation.
I am accepting, for present, the implication of the question that this particular objective / obligation is to be verified within the stated period. This initial forecast reflects concern as to items 2 and 3 above.
